title: 104_s598
content: The Act titled "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increases taxes on tobacco products. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" raises taxes on cigars and cigarettes. For cigars, the tax rate is increased to $5.8125 per thousand, and for large cigars weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand, the tax is 65.875% of the selling price but not exceeding $155 per thousand. For cigarettes, the tax rate is raised to $62 per thousand. The tax rates on tobacco products were increased in the "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995." The tax rates for cigarette papers, cigarette tubes, snuff, and chewing tobacco were also adjusted in the amendment. For example, the tax rate on cigarette papers was changed from 0.75 cents to 3.875 cents, and the tax rate on snuff was changed from 36 cents to $1.86. The tax rates on tobacco products were increased in the "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995." The tax rates for cigarette papers, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco were adjusted. For example, the tax rate on pipe tobacco was changed from 67.5 cents to $3.4875. The amendments apply to tobacco products removed after December 31, 1995. Additionally, a tax of $1.86 per pound was imposed on roll-your-own tobacco. The tax rates on tobacco products were increased in 1995. Amendments were made to define roll-your-own tobacco and include it in the tax regulations. The tax rates on tobacco products were increased in 1995, with amendments made to include roll-your-own tobacco in the tax regulations. Additionally, a new paragraph was inserted for individuals producing tobacco products for personal consumption. The tax rates on tobacco products were increased in 1995, with amendments made to include roll-your-own tobacco in the tax regulations. A new item was added to the table of chapters for subtitle E of the Code, replacing the item relating to chapter 52 with a new one. The amendments made in 1995 included roll-your-own tobacco in the tax regulations, with an effective date after December 31, 1995. A transitional rule allowed certain individuals to continue engaging in the tobacco business pending final action on their application. The transitional rule allowed individuals to continue engaging in the tobacco business pending final action on their application. Taxes were imposed on various tobacco products held for sale before January 1, 1996. Taxes on cigarettes vary based on weight and size, ranging from $50 to $105 per thousand. Cigarette papers are taxed at 3.125 cents for every 50 papers, with additional charges for larger sizes. Cigarette tubes are taxed at 6.25 cents for every 50 tubes. Taxes on tobacco products vary based on type and weight. Snuff is taxed at $1.50 per pound, chewing tobacco at 50 cents per pound, and pipe tobacco at $2.8125 per pound. Additional taxes apply for fractional parts of a pound. Liabilities for these taxes are determined for individuals holding these products on January 1, 1996. The tax imposed on tobacco products is due and payable on February 15, 1996, following the same method as for cigars, cigarettes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco. The terms for these products are defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The taxes imposed on cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco do not apply to retail stocks held on January 1, 1996. Additionally, certain tobacco products in foreign trade zones are exempt from taxes if determined before January 1, 1996, and entered into the US customs territory after that date. Certain tobacco products in foreign trade zones are exempt from taxes if determined before January 1, 1996, and entered into the US customs territory after that date. These products shall be subject to the tax imposed and treated as being held on January 1, 1996, for sale. (1) In general, Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new section related to trust fund code. SEC. 9512. TOBACCO CONVERSION TRUST FUND. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund is established in the Treasury, funded by a percentage of revenue increases from tobacco-related amendments. The fund supports farmers transitioning from tobacco to other crops and provides grants or loans to communities and individuals. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund supports economic diversification plans for communities and individuals involved in tobacco production by providing grants or loans for transitioning to alternative crops. This assistance may include the government purchasing tobacco allotments to retire them from farmers choosing to exit tobacco production. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund provides support for communities and individuals transitioning from tobacco production to alternative crops.
